categories.name: Spending & Contracts
categories.description: Questions about how the council spends public money

templates.title: Purchase Card Policy and Oversight
templates.why: Purchase cards allow council staff to make direct purchases. Understanding the controls in place helps ensure public money is properly managed.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request:

1. The council's current Purchase Card Policy document
2. The number of active purchase cards issued to staff
3. The approval and oversight process for purchase card transactions
4. Any internal audit reports relating to purchase card usage from 2021 onwards
5. Whether any purchase card transactions have been flagged as inappropriate or required repayment in the last 3 years
templates.context: In 2025, a national review found Whitehall procurement card spending had reached £675 million over five years, leading to approximately 10,000 cards being cancelled.

templates.title: Top 10 Suppliers by Value
templates.why: Understanding which suppliers receive the most public money helps assess whether procurement is competitive and delivers value for money.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request:

1. A list of the council's top 10 suppliers by total payment value for each financial year from 2021/22 to 2024/25
2. For each supplier: the total amount paid, the services provided, and whether the contract was competitively tendered
3. Whether any of these suppliers have been subject to performance reviews or contract disputes
4. Any benchmarking data comparing costs with similar authorities
templates.context: Identifying the largest suppliers helps residents understand where public money flows and whether procurement processes ensure value for money.

categories.name: Governance & Decision Making
categories.description: Questions about how decisions are made and who is accountable

templates.title: Senior Officer Pay and Structure
templates.why: Understanding senior pay helps assess whether the council's management structure represents value for money.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request:

1. The current pay scales for all officers at Head of Service level and above
2. The total remuneration package (including pension contributions, bonuses, and benefits) for each post at this level
3. Any severance or redundancy payments made to senior officers since April 2021
4. The current management structure chart showing all posts at Head of Service level and above
5. The pay multiple ratio between the Chief Executive's total remuneration and the median earnings of all council employees
templates.context: Councils are required to publish a Pay Policy Statement annually, but these often lack the detail needed to fully understand senior pay arrangements. The pay multiple ratio is a key indicator of proportionality.

templates.title: Councillor Allowances and Expenses
templates.why: Councillors receive allowances from public funds. Full transparency about these costs supports democratic accountability.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request:

1. The total allowances paid to each individual councillor for each financial year from 2021/22 to 2024/25
2. A breakdown by type of allowance (basic, special responsibility, travel, subsistence)
3. Any claims for equipment, broadband, or other expenses
4. The recommendations of the Independent Remuneration Panel and whether they were accepted or modified
templates.context: Councillor allowances are published but often not in a format that makes comparison easy. Full breakdowns help residents understand the total cost of their elected representatives.

categories.name: Property & Assets
categories.description: Questions about council-owned land, buildings, and investments

templates.title: Council Property Asset Register
templates.why: Understanding what assets the council owns helps assess how effectively public property is being used.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request:

1. A complete list of all land and property assets owned by the council
2. For each asset: the current use, estimated value, and any rental income generated
3. A list of any properties that are currently vacant or unused
4. Any disposals (sales) of council property since April 2021 and the sale prices achieved
templates.context: Councils are required to publish an asset register under the Transparency Code, but the published data is often incomplete or outdated.

templates.title: Council Insurance Costs
templates.why: Understanding insurance costs helps assess value for money in this significant but rarely scrutinised area of spending.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request:

1. The total annual cost of all insurance premiums paid by the council for each year from 2021/22 to 2025/26
2. A breakdown by category of cover (property, liability, motor, cyber, etc.)
3. Whether the council uses a broker and their fees
4. The number and total value of insurance claims made in each year
5. Any self-insurance or excess arrangements
templates.context: Insurance is a significant but rarely scrutinised cost for councils. Understanding the full picture of premiums, claims, and self-insurance helps assess whether arrangements deliver value for money.

categories.name: Services & Performance
categories.description: Questions about how well council services are performing

templates.title: Council Tax Collection Performance
templates.why: Understanding council tax collection rates and outstanding debt helps assess whether the approach to revenue collection is effective.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request:

1. The council tax collection rate for each year from 2021/22 to 2024/25
2. The total outstanding council tax debt as at 31 March each year
3. The amount spent on council tax recovery and enforcement each year
4. The amount of council tax debt written off each year
5. Whether any collection cases have been referred to bailiffs and the associated costs
6. Benchmarking data comparing collection rates with CIPFA nearest neighbours
templates.context: Council tax collection rates vary significantly between authorities. Understanding the full picture of collection costs versus debt recovered helps assess whether the approach is effective.

templates.title: Local Government Reorganisation Costs
templates.why: Lancashire is undergoing local government reorganisation. Residents deserve to know the full cost of preparation work.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request:

1. The total amount spent on local government reorganisation (LGR) preparations to date, broken down by category (consultancy, staff time, legal advice, etc.)
2. A list of all external consultants or advisors engaged in connection with LGR, including their fees
3. Any budget allocated for LGR-related activity in 2025/26 and future years
4. How LGR costs are being funded — from reserves, existing budgets, or additional borrowing
5. Any business cases or impact assessments produced regarding the reorganisation
templates.context: As Lancashire progresses through local government reorganisation, costs are likely to increase significantly. Similar processes at other councils have cost millions. Understanding these costs early supports accountability.

categories.name: Auto-Detected from DOGE Analysis
categories.description: FOI templates automatically generated from AI DOGE anomaly detection. Each template targets a specific finding with pre-filled questions.

templates.title: Duplicate Payment Detection — £314,700
templates.why: AI DOGE identified £314,700 across 96 high-confidence duplicate payment groups. Each group shares the same supplier, amount, and approximate date.
templates.template:
Dear FOI Officer,

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request:

1. The council's duplicate payment detection procedures and software
2. How many duplicate payments have been identified and recovered in each financial year since 2021/22
3. The total value of duplicate payments identified and recovered
4. Whether the council uses NFI (National Fraud Initiative) data matching for duplicate detection
5. Any internal audit reports on accounts payable controls since 2021
templates.context: The National Fraud Initiative estimates councils lose £100M+ annually to duplicate payments. DOGE analysis detected £314,700 in potential duplicates at Ribble Valley Borough Council.

rights: Anyone can make an FOI request — you don't need to give a reason
The council must respond within 20 working days
Information should be free, though the council can charge for printing
If refused, you can request an internal review
If still unsatisfied, you can appeal to the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO)
tips: Be specific — vague requests are easier to refuse
Ask for documents, not opinions or explanations
Reference specific time periods (e.g. 'from April 2021 to March 2025')
If you know a specific document exists, ask for it by name
Keep requests focused on one topic for faster responses
